column20: For trigger weights, let the "unselectable" bins have the same weight as the next bins up.  This is to cover ultra-rare cases where a photon is moved across the bin boundary.  Impact is on MC weight only and expected to be very small; this is mostly because accounting for 0 weights is a little trickier and it's better not to have to do it.
column21: For trigger weights, let the "unselectable" bins have the same weight as the next bins up.  This is to cover ultra-rare cases where a photon is moved across the bin boundary.  Impact is on MC weight only and expected to be very small; this is mostly because accounting for 0 weights is a little trickier and it's better not to have to do it.

column20: The JetValidationTreeProducer.cc now has additional branches for weights (just for Heppi plotting convenience, always set=1) and passesRMSIndex, to aid comparison with the VBFTag. The jetIndex has been altered to not count photons and there is now a boolean controlling whether the photon matching is done in the previous way or in the same way as the VBFTag. The config file you wrote allowing the VBFTag and the JetValidation to run over the same events is also included

column13: creating the puweight output branch in GlobalVariablesDumper also for data
column20: This allows merging of dumped trees from MC and data with hadd (otherwise, data trees which do not have the puweight branch are ignored by hadd). Setting puweight to one for data in GlobalVariablesComputer.
column21: This allows merging of dumped trees from MC and data with hadd (otherwise, data trees which do not have the puweight branch are ignored by hadd). Setting puweight to one for data in GlobalVariablesComputer.

column13: creating the puweight output branch in GlobalVariablesDumper also for data
column20: This allows merging of dumped trees from MC and data with hadd (otherwise, data trees which do not have the puweight branch are ignored by hadd). Setting puweight to one for data in GlobalVariablesComputer.
column21: @andreh7 What happens if the pu reweight is turned off for MC?  In this case it looks like only the data will have this branch and again there will be hadd issues..!   (On the other hand maybe this is not a case we should support at all..)

column13: creating the puweight output branch in GlobalVariablesDumper also for data
column20: This allows merging of dumped trees from MC and data with hadd (otherwise, data trees which do not have the puweight branch are ignored by hadd). Setting puweight to one for data in GlobalVariablesComputer.
column21:
good point... the branch is created unconditionally in the patched version ( https://github.com/andreh7/flashgg/blob/2016-04-22-puweight-var/Taggers/src/GlobalVariablesDumper.cc#L83 ) so there should be no problem at the level of hadd.
Admittedly this is wasting a bit of space in the output tree when pileup reweighting is disabled.
On the other hand, it's flashgg/MetaData/python/JobConfig.py which enables pileup reweighting (if puTarget is specified) except for data, so GlobalVariablesDumper currently can't not know if pileup reweighting is disabled in its configuration because the job is running on data or because it was disabled for all jobs.
One could modify JobConfig.py set the parameter 'puReweight' to True also for data and pass the pileup weights as it if were MC. The patch already sets the output variable puweight to one in GlobalVariablesComputer.cc if evt.isRealData() is true, independent of whether pileup reweighting is enabled or not.
The only other place where the parameter 'puReWeight' appears is in Validation/plugins/globelikeTreeMakerWithTagSorter.cc but this ignores pileup reweighting for data already and creates the branch whether pileup reweighting is enabled or not.
The easiest solution would be to create the puweight branch (in GlobalVariablesDumper) whether pileup reweighting is enabled or not.
However I just noticed that for MC and pileup reweighting disabled, cache_.puweight is not correctly initialized in GlobalVariablesComputer.cc, I can update the pull request.

https://github.com/cms-analysis/flashgg/blob/master/MetaData/data/cross_sections.json#L14

#624
Commit Summary

class SamplesManager: changed default cross section from 0 to None so we can detect if the cross section was not specified in the json file
class JobsManager: now checking whether all cross sections are present before submitting the jobs (which would then crash later because the cross section is not found)
update on checking cross sections in class JobsManager before submitting jobs: fixed typo

column20:
Hello Seth,
here you can find the modifications for adding the egamma recipes inside electrons in the proper way using egamma POG maps, as discussed by email. Since i did not touch the taggers yet and strictly added information, it should be backward compatible as you said. Once the new microAOD will be done with those electrons, we can move forward and change the way we select electrons in the taggers.
Best,
Julie

column20:
This branch can be used to run flashgg including the MET correction and uncertainties tool in 80X.
It should be ok to be run in 76X.
The following files have been changed:
In setup.sh:
-> 1. Add additional CMSSW packages
git cms-addpkg PhysicsTools/PatUtils
git cms-addpkg PhysicsTools/PatAlgos
-> 2.Change these two lines:
https://github.com/cms-sw/cmssw/blob/CMSSW_7_4_X/PhysicsTools/PatUtils/python/tool
/runMETCorrectionsAndUncertainties.py#L722-L723 to:
#jetCorrInputFileName = cms.FileInPath(jetUncInfos["jecUncFile"] ), #jecUncertaintyFile),
jetCorrUncertaintyTag = cms.string("Uncertainty"), #jecUncertaintyTag),
In /MicroAOD/python/ add:
https://github.com/lsoffi/flashgg/blob/topic_metsyst/MicroAOD/python/**flashggMETs_cff.py**
In  MicroAOD/test/ add:
https://github.com/lsoffi/flashgg/blob/topic_metsyst/MicroAOD/test/**Fall15_25nsV2_DATA.db**
https://github.com/lsoffi/flashgg/blob/topic_metsyst/MicroAOD/test/**Fall15_25nsV2_MC.db**
https://github.com/lsoffi/flashgg/blob/topic_metsyst/MicroAOD/test/**microAODstdWithMETCorr.py**
In MetaData/work modify:
https://github.com/lsoffi/flashgg/blob/topic_metsyst/MetaData/work/**crabConfig_TEMPLATE.py**#L19
https://github.com/lsoffi/flashgg/blob/topic_metsyst/MetaData/work/**prepareCrabJobs.py**#L233
NB: The only parameter that has to be changed by hand,if one runs either on data or MC , for the time being is the "isMC" flag in the crabConfig.py produced.

jetCorrUncertaintyTag = cms.string("Uncertainty"), #jecUncertaintyTag),

https://github.com/lsoffi/flashgg/blob/topic_metsyst/MicroAOD/python/**flashggMETs_cff.py**
In  MicroAOD/test/ add:
https://github.com/lsoffi/flashgg/blob/topic_metsyst/MicroAOD/test/**Fall15_25nsV2_DATA.db**
https://github.com/lsoffi/flashgg/blob/topic_metsyst/MicroAOD/test/**Fall15_25nsV2_MC.db**

https://github.com/lsoffi/flashgg/blob/topic_metsyst/MetaData/work/**prepareCrabJobs.py**#L233

column21:
@lsoffi Why do we check out two packages in order to make one small change to a configuration file?  I looked at the code and I don't see any reason we can't run the existing python tool with some appropriate changes to the input (or modification of the output) in our own configuration files.  For everyone's information, the latest version of the methods in question are here:
https://github.com/cms-sw/cmssw/blob/CMSSW_8_0_X/PhysicsTools/PatUtils/python/tools/runMETCorrectionsAndUncertainties.py

column21:
I have to actually test in 808, but it looks like the changes to patutils are no longer needed.
The configuration now skips the line livia removed if the local JEC file isn't defined (so I think that's good).
https://github.com/cms-sw/cmssw/blob/CMSSW_7_4_X/PhysicsTools/PatUtils/python/tools/runMETCorrectionsAndUncertainties.py#L720-731
https://github.com/cms-sw/cmssw/blob/CMSSW_8_0_X/PhysicsTools/PatUtils/python/tools/runMETCorrectionsAndUncertainties.py#L768-788
For the JEC tag, it looks like it has been properly initialized in 80x to the value we want.  This wasn't the case in 74x.  Again, testing is needed to make sure I understand the behavior, but I suspect it will work out of the box in 80x:
https://github.com/cms-sw/cmssw/blob/CMSSW_8_0_X/PhysicsTools/PatUtils/python/tools/runMETCorrectionsAndUncertainties.py#L60

column21:
Sure, I'll provide it.  It runs no problem in 808 without the modifications to cmssw.
I'm also trying to put the db files in the /data directory and have crab access them from there, as then we don't need to modify the prepareCrabJobs or crabTemplate.  I haven't got that to work yet, the files are of course copied, but I haven't figured out what to have the python code look for to find the db files loaded from the /data directory.  I tried to follow the procedure in other files which access /data/files.
I'll add a pull request today, hopefully, a version which doesn't need to modify crab_TEMPLATE and prepareCrabJobs.py.

column20:
Updates to properly treat stage2 L1 for HLT tag-probe.  Removed some old HLT code.  Added tnp code specific for the HLT analysis to avoid conflicts with anyone looking at energy scale (etc) on Z->ee.
Setup.sh now grabs from my cmssw area (instead of matteo's) for the 80x fixes to egm-tnp.
I also added the current proper global tag for 2016 prompt reco.  Perhaps, we don't want that loaded by default until things have settled down?

column21:
@mplaner This setup causes a truly mind-boggling array of packages to be added by CMSSW:
Alignment         Calibration  CondFormats    DQM          DataFormats     FWCore              Geometry          L1Trigger     RecoEgamma        RecoTauTag
CalibCalorimetry  CommonTools  CondTools      DQMOffline   EgammaAnalysis  Fireworks           HLTrigger         MuonAnalysis  RecoLocalTracker  RecoTracker
CalibFormats      CondCore     Configuration  DQMServices  EventFilter     GeneratorInterface  HLTriggerOffline  PhysicsTools  RecoMuon          flashgg
Is this an issue you've seen?  Is there anything that can be done about it?

column21: One option is to use the --unsafe option of git cms-merge-topic, which skips the dependency checking.  In that case we just have to add all the necessary packages explicitly in flashgg.  (thanks @yhaddad for the suggestion)

column13: remove duplicated lines, slightly widen allowed object weights

column20:
This PR contains the new weights for the Diphoton MVA, trained in 80x. The retraining has been performed using the retrained photonID with the Moriond vertex, a beamspot size of 3.7cm and extra-smearing corrections obtained on 800/pb.
The untagged definition is re-optimised for a scenario of 6/fb.
column21:
This PR contains the new weights for the Diphoton MVA, trained in 80x. The retraining has been performed using the retrained photonID with the Moriond vertex, a beamspot size of 3.7cm and extra-smearing corrections obtained on 800/pb.
The untagged definition is re-optimised for a scenario of 6/fb.

column20:
Merged with diphoton high mass catalog
Some samples present in two flavours, i.e. with a second extension _ext* have been merged together

N.B.
Because of a different file content (flashggElectrons vs. flashggSelectedElectrons), the diphotons:EXOSpring16_v1 has ben preferred to have a large and consistent set of data.
To run flashgg on it, add this code to your cfg (from Martina):
from flashgg.MicroAOD.flashggLeptonSelectors_cff import flashggSelectedElectrons
process.flashggSelectedElectrons = flashggSelectedElectrons.clone()
process.p = cms.Path(process.flashggSelectedElectrons* process.BlaBla)

where BlaBla is the rest of your usual path.
Meanwhile counter-actions are being taken to fix the issue in a more general way.
TheDoubleEG dataset is now:
/DoubleEG/musella-EXOSpring16_v1_p3-diphotons_80_v1-v0-Run2016B-PromptReco-v1-ea408274daa18c6402a808da38fd2b89/USER

/DoubleEG/musella-EXOSpring16_v1_p8-Moriond16WSFinal-106-ga327d4a-v0-Run2016B-PromptReco-v2-a5f1c0c964d9d1f7d2e18cd5bbce5233/USER

column13: support for 80x pileup jet id mva, store in flashgg::Jet
column20:
Support the latest 80x pileup id mva, so that we can do further study as part of the VBF tag.  This is needed for MicroAOD processing. Important note: setup.sh is changed
This is not super-well validated but it's better than nothing (and certainly harmless).  Some details:

MiniAODv2 had a buggy version of the id mva, so to validate I had to run the buggy code to confirm that the ID MVA value was the same one stored, for 0th vertices.  This was only true most of the time, but I assume the differences come down to running on Candidates in MiniAOD-production vs running on PackedCandidates later.
After this validation I include a version of the code to fix the bug.  Note that this is in a new cmssw branch that's included from setup.sh
Next I edited the code so that it would respect our non-0th vertex choice.  The results seem sane-ish but I have no way to validate this but look at distributions.  That's why this first pass is needed in MicroAOD
column21:
Support the latest 80x pileup id mva, so that we can do further study as part of the VBF tag.  This is needed for MicroAOD processing. Important note: setup.sh is changed
This is not super-well validated but it's better than nothing (and certainly harmless).  Some details:

MiniAODv2 had a buggy version of the id mva, so to validate I had to run the buggy code to confirm that the ID MVA value was the same one stored, for 0th vertices.  This was only true most of the time, but I assume the differences come down to running on Candidates in MiniAOD-production vs running on PackedCandidates later.
After this validation I include a version of the code to fix the bug.  Note that this is in a new cmssw branch that's included from setup.sh
Next I edited the code so that it would respect our non-0th vertex choice.  The results seem sane-ish but I have no way to validate this but look at distributions.  That's why this first pass is needed in MicroAOD

column13: added a parameter applyCorrections to DiPhotonWithUpdatedPhoIdMVAProducer
column20:
To be able to disable the corrections of the photon id MVA input variables for testing purposes.
The official version of the code tries to disable corrections when the file given with the 'correctionFile' parameter does not exist. However, this generates an exception:
python encountered the error: <type 'exceptions.RuntimeError'>
edm::FileInPath unable to find file

This patch allows to disable the corrections explicitly (the default setting of the new parameter is true in the corresponding _cfi.py file).

column13: Changes for pileup jet id studies
column20:
The current Pu Jet ID training was done with some buggy variable definitions.  I've had to play with the behavior of the PU Jet ID module (new tag in setup.sh) to get the outputs close to those on AOD.  Some (but not all) of the recent improvements from Jet MET had to be switched back.  The new debugging tools I used to figure this out are included in this PR.
I have not yet implemented saving the variables, to allow MVA re-evaluation, because the buggy internal variable definitions go into the JetMET pileup jet id object itself.  But I will implemented some sort of workaround before we do a full-scale production with pu jet id.
A small production (DY+Jets, DoubleEG, SingleElectron) was submitted to study distributions, especially for standard vs. non-standard vertices.  Details of the production included in the PR.

column13: Fix `[Errno 36] File name too long` error when checking files
column20:
The error is raised by fggCheckFile.py when called from within sample_utils.pyif the dataset name is too (sic).
This fix/improvement introduces a sha256() of the dataset name in the temporary file creation in sample_utils.py so to have a unique filename with constant length.
Tested by checking few datasets both interactively and via lsf.

column13: double-check to avoid false resubmissions during SGE reboot
column20: At IC, occasional reboots of the sge master process can cause the existing code to decide all jobs failed and restart.  With this change, the code checks 12 times over a full minute before it believes a null answer.  Beyond helping with the restarts, should cause no impact except for a slight delay when all jobs really are finished.

Beyond helping with the restarts, should cause no impact except for a slight delay when all jobs really are finished.

Update with various tweaks as used in workspace submission for ICHEP preapproval:

Print lumisection list for debugging of log files

Use June22 for smears/scales by default
JSON files for latest catalogue: RunIISpring16DR80X-2_1_0-25ns_ICHEP16
Job sh tweaks, new puTarget
Sideband event printouts developed for TTH debugging are generally useful, on by default

wh_sig_jobs.sh / zh_sig_jobs.sh  [separate folders to avoid filename clashes]
data_jobs.sh

column13: Pattern matching when reviewing catalogues and update to RunIISpring16DR80X-2_1_0-25ns_ICHEP16
column20:
Hello,
with this PR is possible to match a pattern in the dataset name when reviewing a catalog using fggManageSamples.py
I used the new tool to merge the GluGluHToGG_M125_13TeV_amcatnloFXFX_pythia8 with its extension. This comes useful to avoid inadvertently picking also the same dataset with material variation in the catalog when running on muAODs. The merged catalogue is included in this PR.
Bests,
Vittorio

column13: Adding MET filter production to miniAOD
column20:
Added the three missing MET filters to microAOD production.
Only concerns those analyses which use MET (can now grab the filter results via triggerResults).  See example in MicroAOD/test/metFilters_test.py.
TriggerResults::PAT: MC precomputed MET flags
TriggerResults::RECO: data precomputed MET flags
TriggerResults::FLASHggMicroAOD: MC/data MET flags computed in flashgg

Mass resolution decorrelation, tags and workspace configuration for fiducial xsec measurement
column20:
Hi all,
this PR includes:

the machinery needed to decorrelate the mass resolution, calculated on the fly for every event;
additional tags and producers to run sigmaM categorisation instead of the usual tags;
changes in workspaceStd.py so that from one python both versions of the workspaces (standard analysis and fiducial measurement) can be run. The default is the standard analysis, the fiducial one can be turned on specifying doFiducial=True on the command line.

I checked that the workspaces produced with this PR and with the master are perfectly synchronised on a sub-sample of signal events.
Since the PR makes the developments performed for the fiducial analysis converge into the master after quite some time, I think it would be good if someone could double-check it before merging.
Let me know if you have comments or suggestions,
Vittorio

column21:
Hi @vtavolar - overall I like how you've organized this.  Keeping the flashgg master so it supports multiple measurements and analysis is something we'll need more of in the future, and this is a good model.  Some questions/comments

Is Systematics/python/escales/Golden22June.py used anywhere?
There is probably some common code for switching to the fiducial in workspaceStd.py (and other configs) that could be moved to Systematics/python/SystematicsCustomize.py ... but I don't think this is needed for now, just a note for the future.

column21:
Hi Seth,
thanks for having a look at this. About your comments:

the file is not used anywhere for the workspace production, I'll remove it from the PR
I agree on that, I guess for instance the manipulation of  the tagsequence and the tagsorter would better belong to the systematics customization config. As you said, we can keep it as it is for the moment and organise it better in the future.

Thanks,
Vittorio

column20:
I discovered that running on lxplus, where files are copied at the end of the jobs, if outputFile is specified as a per-job argument, the expected subdir is not applied to the given argument.  This PR fixes it at least for this use case.
I cc @vtavolar because we were discussing it this morning, and cc @musella in case he can see a way this change would break some other use case.

column13: lower weight bound in tag sorter to 0.35 (one tth event)
column20:
There's one signal TTH event whose object weight was right at the lower boundary enforced by TagSorter.  It crossed below the boundary due to #717 which lowered some weights very slightly.  So the boundary is widened.
I think such weights in rare instances are not unexpected due to the BTag weights being applied for many jets.  But in case it's worth looking at I cc @saghosh and provide the event info:
----- Begin Fatal Exception 17-Jul-2016 03:32:16 CEST-----------------------
An exception of category 'TagObjectWeight' occurred while
   [0] Processing run: 1 lumi: 1169 event: 476714
   [1] Running path 'p'
   [2] Calling event method for module FlashggTagSorter/'flashggTagSorter'
Exception Message:
 Tag centralWeight=0.395169 outside of bound [0.4,2.5] - flashggTTHLeptonicTag chosen_i=0 - change bounds or debug tag
----- End Fatal Exception -------------------------------------------------
root://eoscms.cern.ch//eos/cms/store/group/phys_higgs/cmshgg/ferriff/flashgg/RunIISpring16DR80X-2_2_0-25ns_ICHEP16_MiniAODv2/2_2_0/ttHJe\

column13: Update for flashgg::Met and met systematics
column20:
Added the flashgg::Met class so that the systematics can be properly loaded.  Once the microAOD have been rerun with the flashgg::Met, then the VHtags and systematics can be uncommented and run safely.
Currently, the Met systematics only use the systematic smearing from the "unclustered" systematics, but additional systematics are in place in the collection and can be added to the systematics simply.
column21:
Added the flashgg::Met class so that the systematics can be properly loaded.  Once the microAOD have been rerun with the flashgg::Met, then the VHtags and systematics can be uncommented and run safely.
Currently, the Met systematics only use the systematic smearing from the "unclustered" systematics, but additional systematics are in place in the collection and can be added to the systematics simply.

column13: fix for using AAA on lxplus
column20:
I've experienced problems using AAA on lxplus/lxbatch with CMSSW_8_0_8, redirection did not
work properly.
A solution which solves this problem was given here: https://hypernews.cern.ch/HyperNews/CMS/get/wanaccess/448/1/1/1.html
This patch implements this solution (setting an environment variable at the beginning of a
job script submitted to LSF).

Also caloClusters are kept so that regression can be potentially rerun.

column20:
I've created the three VH leptonic tags (WH, ZH, and VHloose leptonic).  I fixed the bug in the hadronic channel.  And I kept the old versions of the VH tags available.
All VH tags are off by default.  By uncommenting lines in tagSorter, TagSequence, and workspaceStd, it is possible to run any combination of VH tags.  The lines needed to run the met tags have been added in, then commented out inside workspaceStd as well.
column21:
I've created the three VH leptonic tags (WH, ZH, and VHloose leptonic).  I fixed the bug in the hadronic channel.  And I kept the old versions of the VH tags available.
All VH tags are off by default.  By uncommenting lines in tagSorter, TagSequence, and workspaceStd, it is possible to run any combination of VH tags.  The lines needed to run the met tags have been added in, then commented out inside workspaceStd as well.

column13: Adding b-regression variables to flashgg jets as user floats
column20:
New variables are stored as userFloats on the flashgg::Jets (inhering userFloats methods from pat::Jets).
The new variables are related to jet constituents and secondary vertices.
The adding of these variables (or not) is controlled by the tag "ComputeRegVars" (default true).
They are to be used by the HHbbgg analysis.
(Ignore that the last commit is named "roll back to flashgg master", an extra change was committed in the two previous commits and rolled back.)

column13: propogate duplicate removal to this other file too
Gen variables, extra floats, scripts to reduce ws for differential analysis
column20:
This PR merges the classes for gen-level analysis needed for the differential analysis.
More modifications to the extra floats handling are introduced, in order to allow the possibility to add variables to the workspaces as extra floats.
Few other modifications/improvements are contained in this PR:

additional trees for gen-level analysis;
optimised hadd_workspaces routine, with possibility of parallelization (gain a factor ~400 in wall time);
scripts to reduce and split "inclusive" fiducial workspaces into "differential" workspaces.

I have produced the ws for the main analysis with the master branch and with this branch, and I have obtained the same results (same number of entries in the datasets).
Please let me know if you have comments/requests,
Vittorio

column20:
Modified the JobConfig.py to add one additional option "puSIM" to taking the true MC simulated PU distribution (normalized to 1.0) for PU reweighting. When running the new PU reweighting with the input "puSIM" option, one need to specify the input puSIM values, with the similar usage as "puTarget". For "Spring16 80X" MC samples,  puSIM=0.00131931,0.00230159,0.00346567,0.00483143,0.00642775,0.00836145,0.0107535,0.0135679,0.016785,0.0203496,0.0241871,0.0282775,0.0324902,0.0366713,0.040648,0.0442128,0.0472559,0.0496434,0.0511215,0.0518062,0.0514804,0.0503577,0.0484196,0.0458103,0.0427031,0.0392474,0.0354694,0.0317312,0.0279578,0.0243083,0.0208245,0.0176106,0.0147456,0.0121483,0.0098674,0.0079237,0.00625031,0.00487828,0.00374769,0.00283541,0.0021124,0.00156391,0.00112964,0.00079719,0.000570062,0.000388339,0.000267111,0.000179967,0.000119864,7.76474e-05  (50 values) which were taken from GJet_Pt-40toInf MC sample with simulated events N~58M (almost the same values from DiPhotonJetsBox_MGG-80toInf with ~38M events). See details from slide 6 in ref [1].
Without this "puSIM"  option, the probvalues from OOT cfi file will be used for PU reweighting, which is the same as what we used for ICHEP16.
[1] https://indico.cern.ch/event/566824/contributions/2390463/attachments/1380995/2099339/20161201IssuesOnSigFit_LowMass2016data_HggWorkingMeeting.pdf

column21: @JunquanTao Sorry that I'm a little slow to understand, but this PR is not changing as much as I expected.  The calculation method doesn't change at all; it's simply that the simulated PU event count is being replaced by a user-specified one.  So is the conclusion that the "OOT cfi file" is simply wrong?  Or were we using it the wrong way before?  We need to understand this. cc @ferriff @martinamalberti @musella

column21:
@sethzenz  In this way, others can also compare the validation results from the default one (taking the probValues from the "OOT cfi file" as input) and the user-specified one (taking the suggested puSIM values as input when running fggRunJobs.py ). The input puSIM values can be changed easily according to different simulation condition, such as from Spring16 to Moriond17.
By default in the codes,  the probValues from the "OOT cfi file" were used as input for mcpu  (GlobalVariablesComputer.cc) to calculate the PU weights.  Then PU weight is assigned to each MC event according to the true Npu in this MC event in the codes.
The codes for the calculation of PU weights (GlobalVariablesComputer.cc) will not be problem in technology, if the input mcpu values are reasonable.  As shown in my slide 5 [1] or checked from the "OOT cfi file" directly for Spring16,  the problem is that the probValues are 0 when Npu>38 until Npu up to 50. These 0 values in the denominator for the calculation of PU weights in  GlobalVariablesComputer.cc will  cause PU weight problem, as we have seen from our lower mass signal modeling.
From my investigation with  ICHEP dataset and Spring16 80X DY MC, it's better to use the true simulated PU distributions as  input for the calculation of PU weights, when looking at the Nvtx distributions from Zee data and MC.
With this PR changes, one can also compare the validation results from two methods (probValues from the "OOT cfi file" or from the true simulated PU), with the Zee events from re-reco data and the exist Spring16 MC or  Moriond17 MC in near future.
[1] https://indico.cern.ch/event/566824/contributions/2390463/attachments/1380995/2099339/20161201IssuesOnSigFit_LowMass2016data_HggWorkingMeeting.pdf

@JunquanTao Just to confirm, when you get your better-agreeing plots, you are using the weight output from ntuples coming out of the JobConfig.py code?
I.e. you are not applying any extra weights or external calculations?  (For example, pileup weight is already included in the main weight and should not be applied again.)

column21:
@JunquanTao I'm confused by your statements.  From your presentation, I thought you were using reconstructed nPU from MC and reconstructed nPU from data to derive the weights.  But now it sounds like you are using the true nPU from MC.  But I don't understand how you can get a true nPU from MC greater than what's in the OOT cfi file for the generated MC.
Can you clarify exactly which variables were used for the inputs for your weights?

column21:
@sethzenz : The jet BTagReshapeWeights can be quite small for when light or PU jets have high b discriminator values .
see for example:
https://github.com/cms-analysis/flashgg/blob/master/Systematics/data/CSVv2.csv#L2018
so the limits for the weights might need to be extended.

column13: Split catalog into multiple file to avoid git file size issue
column20:
Catalogs are split automatically in such a way that the size of json files stays reasonable.
In practice the catalog is split in such a way that no file contains information about more than 1k root files.
Datasets are never split, therefore the threshold on the number of files can be passed if the file contains just one dataset.
The dataset is split when the catalogs is written back to disk (after any command that potentially modifies the catalog, such as import, review, check, etc..) and a new command rebuild is added to force the splitting of existing catalogs.

column21:
There is a small issue when running on the data. The sqlite file for DATA has a different name structure than the MC. The code in SystematicsCustomize.py to handle JEC for data [0] is therfore not compatible with this JEC/JES version. This can be fixed quickly by adding these lines in your configuration file,
if customize.processId == "Data":
    process.jec.connect = cms.string('sqlite_file:%s/src/flashgg/Systematics/data/JEC/Spring16_23Sep2016AllV2_DATA.db' % environ['CMSSW_BASE'])
    process.jec.toGet[0].tag = cms.string('JetCorrectorParametersCollection_Spring16_23Sep2016AllV2_DATA_AK4PFchs')
after calling cloneTagSequenceForEachSystematic method.
An example can be found in here [1]
[0] https://github.com/cms-analysis/flashgg/blob/master/Systematics/python/SystematicsCustomize.py#L185-L186
[1] https://github.com/yhaddad/flashgg/blob/topic-rereco-jetcorrections/Taggers/test/ZPlusJetDumper_cfg.py

column13: remove hack now that JEC/JER is updated again
Differentials: trees reduction to ws, global vars binning, CompositeCandidates in the tag
column20:
Dear all,
this PR contains the status of the framework in view of the differential measurements for Moriond. It introduces the following features:

"inclusive" trees are produced instead of workspaces, which are obtained at a later stage when splitting the events into the bins/processes of the analysis;
the handling of the binning of the global variables has been improved, adding also the possibility to specify a variable binning;
CompositeCandidate objects are added to the differential tag. This allows to attach, for instance, the jet objects to the tag, taking advantage of the tag replication for systematic variations.

I would suggest not merge it just yet because I haven't had time to check that no variation is introduced in the standard workflow.
Bests,
Vittorio

column13: trigger scale factors updated with full 2016 data
column20:
Overall, the efficiency has dropped a bit due to increase PU.  I tightened up the R9 turn on bin (wrt ICHEP 2016) to better reflect the R9 turn on.
Additionally, the fits are better due to less background -> tighter tag selection than ICHEP 2016.
Based on presented results here: https://indico.cern.ch/event/605395/contributions/2462511/attachments/1405295/2146740/2017_02_01_trigger.pdf

column13: Disable r9 function so user knows which r9 they are calling
column20:
Override the r9 function in flashgg::Photon.h so that it causes an exception.  If user really wants the older implementation of r9 rather than full5x5_r9, they must call the new function old_r9.
Example error message:
----- Begin Fatal Exception 08-Feb-2017 16:23:37 CET-----------------------
An exception of category 'Ambiguous R9' occurred while
   [0] Processing run: 1 lumi: 2 event: 206
   [1] Running path 'p'
   [2] Calling event method for module FlashggDiPhotonSystematicProducer/'flashggDiPhotonSystematics'
Exception Message:
 Please call flashgg::Photon::old_r9 or flashgg::Photon::full5x5_r9
----- End Fatal Exception -------------------------------------------------

column13: update to CMSSW_8_0_26_patch1, split off uAOD recipes into bigger set…
column20: …up file
column21:
Hi,

I don't think it is a good idea to split recipes for uAOD production
and post-uAOD processing. It is yet one more hassle for people doing
analysis and/or needing from time to time to independently produce and
look at uAODs.

Why should this be needed? Do we really gain so much by having this split?

I feel we are diverging towards complications.

My 2 cents,

column13: update to CMSSW_8_0_26_patch1, split off uAOD recipes into bigger set…
column20: …up file
column21:
The problem is branches out of our control that check out too many packages especially as the release number advances.  Below are the current lists without and with uAOD support included.  I have also emailed some of the people responsible for the recipes but I do not know if a fix will come soon.

column13: keep debug variables, do not keep old rechits
column20:
For ReMiniAOD they now list some collections that might be useful for debugging [1], which have been added.  Some extra debug collections were accidentally kept so far [2], and they are removed.  I don't anticipate that the existing ReMiniAOD "test" jobs will need to be rerun.
[1] https://twiki.cern.ch/twiki/bin/view/CMSPublic/ReMiniAOD03Feb2017Notes

bool                                  "particleFlowEGammaGSFixed"   "dupECALClusters"   "PAT"
edm::EDCollection              "ecalMultiAndGSGlobalRecHitEB"   "hitsNotReplaced"   "PAT"

[2] And also I found some debugging collections that we were keeping by accident in the ReMiniAOD test jobs.  These will be removed and should make the next jobs smaller:
< edm::SortedCollection<EcalRecHit,edm::StrictWeakOrdering >    "reducedEgammaBeforeGSFix"   "reducedEBRecHits"   "PAT"
16d16
< edm::SortedCollection<EcalRecHit,edm::StrictWeakOrdering >    "reducedEgammaBeforeGSFix"   "reducedEERecHits"   "PAT"
18d17
< edm::SortedCollection<EcalRecHit,edm::StrictWeakOrdering >    "reducedEgammaBeforeGSFix"   "reducedESRecHits"   "PAT"
22d20
< vectorreco::CaloCluster             "reducedEgammaBeforeGSFix"   "reducedEBEEClusters"   "PAT"
24d21
< vectorreco::CaloCluster             "reducedEgammaBeforeGSFix"   "reducedESClusters"   "PAT"
26d22
< vectorreco::GsfElectronCore         "reducedEgammaBeforeGSFix"   "reducedGedGsfElectronCores"   "PAT"

column13: Herwig DY xs so jobs do not crash, value same as pythia
ReMiniAOD catalogue, mostly complete, plus tools for reading
column20:
In this PR is a mostly complete catalogue for the ReMiniAOD to uAOD processing: ReMiniAOD-03Feb2017-2_5_X.  Most datasets are greater than 90% done, except for SingleElectron Run2016E which is only about 70% done.  (Jobs still running.)  So far only one run period for DoubleMuon has been run, 2016G; more can be run if checks show significant differences in any DoubleMuon studies using the 2016G dataset.
Metadata python changes are required to handle two new wrinkles in this catalogue:

First deployment of catalog splitting tools by @musella from PR #804 - some additional updates required to run.
One dataset (you don't need to know which, but it's SingleElectron 2016B) was output to T2_UK_London_IC.  However, you can still run over these files using fggRunJobs.py in the usual way: if useAAA=0 then a special prefix specified in the json file for the dataset will be introduced for these files. An example direct file path for IC is root://gfe02.grid.hep.ph.ic.ac.uk:1095//store/group/phys_higgs/cmshgg/sethzenz/flashgg/ReMiniAOD-03Feb2017-2_5_0-test/2_5_0/SingleElectron/ReMiniAOD-03Feb2017-2_5_0-test-2_5_0-v0-Run2016B-03Feb2017_ver2-v2/170213_113017/0000/myMicroAODOutputFile_179.root and I've tested that this works from lxbatch at CERN.

These changes should not create issues, and should be invisible to ordinary users, but of course there may be unforeseen cases. Let me know if any problems arise.
The catalog name is ReMiniAOD-03Feb2017-2_5_X, which combines two different submission catalogues.  The difference between 2_5_0 and 2_5_1 is covered in #857 but the files can be run in the same way for normal jobs.

fggManageSamples.py -C ReMiniAOD-03Feb2017-2_5_X getlumi "/DoubleEG*" output=DoubleEG_sofar.json
[sethzenz@lxplus012]~% brilcalc lumi -b "STABLE BEAMS" --normtag /afs/cern.ch/user/l/lumipro/public/Normtags/normtag_DATACERT.json -u /fb -i /afs/cern.ch/work/s/sethzenz/fromscratch142/CMSSW_8_0_26_patch1/src/flashgg/DoubleEG_sofar.json

| 144   | 392  | 230418 | 230413 | 37.026            | 35.526           |

column20:
In this PR is a mostly complete catalogue for the ReMiniAOD to uAOD processing: ReMiniAOD-03Feb2017-2_5_X.  Most datasets are greater than 90% done, except for SingleElectron Run2016E which is only about 70% done.  (Jobs still running.)  So far only one run period for DoubleMuon has been run, 2016G; more can be run if checks show significant differences in any DoubleMuon studies using the 2016G dataset.
Metadata python changes are required to handle two new wrinkles in this catalogue:

First deployment of catalog splitting tools by @musella from PR #804 - some additional updates required to run.
One dataset (you don't need to know which, but it's SingleElectron 2016B) was output to T2_UK_London_IC.  However, you can still run over these files using fggRunJobs.py in the usual way: if useAAA=0 then a special prefix specified in the json file for the dataset will be introduced for these files. An example direct file path for IC is root://gfe02.grid.hep.ph.ic.ac.uk:1095//store/group/phys_higgs/cmshgg/sethzenz/flashgg/ReMiniAOD-03Feb2017-2_5_0-test/2_5_0/SingleElectron/ReMiniAOD-03Feb2017-2_5_0-test-2_5_0-v0-Run2016B-03Feb2017_ver2-v2/170213_113017/0000/myMicroAODOutputFile_179.root and I've tested that this works from lxbatch at CERN.

These changes should not create issues, and should be invisible to ordinary users, but of course there may be unforeseen cases. Let me know if any problems arise.
The catalog name is ReMiniAOD-03Feb2017-2_5_X, which combines two different submission catalogues.  The difference between 2_5_0 and 2_5_1 is covered in #857 but the files can be run in the same way for normal jobs.

column13: 10 jet collections, because there exists an event which needs over 8
column20:
This is a change for MicroAOD, required to process one ReMiniAOD event that would otherwise crash, which is in this file: /store/data/Run2016E/DoubleEG/MINIAOD/03Feb2017-v1/80000/CA5635A7-ACEA-E611-B569-002590D9D8D4.root	   The exact event number and the details of the crash are here:
----- Begin Fatal Exception 16-Feb-2017 13:22:57 CET-----------------------
An exception of category 'Configuration' occurred while
   [0] Processing run: 277127 lumi: 809 event: 1511130886
   [1] Running path 'p'
   [2] Calling event method for module FlashggDiPhotonProducer/'flashggDiPhotons'
Exception Message:
 We need to setJetCollectionIndex to a value more than MaxJetCollections=8 -- you must reconfigure and rerun
----- End Fatal Exception -------------------------------------------------

This fix is related to the fact that we run a separate round of PFCHS clustering for each vertex that has an attached diphoton, as well as the 0th vertex, so that whichever diphoton we pick later we have a different jet collection.  Usually this is only 1 or 2 jet collections, but it can rarely be more.  (If there are 4 EM objects in the event, there are 432/2 = 12 candidate diphotons, each of which in principle can be matched to a different vertex, although in practice this would be a very strange event.)   For technical reasons, we have to specify a fixed maximum number of jet collections in the configuration.  Formerly, this was 8 and there was no problem, but in the ReMiniAOD it seems that more is required.  I changed it to 10.
I've confirmed the event above can be processed with the current fix, and I am now resubmitting the 1 job to complete the DoubleEG catalog.  For the benefit of any other people submitting their own uAOD, I will send a detailed email on this procedure to the flashgg list.

Hi all,
in this PR I include in flashgg the new set of energy scale and smearing corrections taken from gfasanel/ScalesSmearings@bf3fd0e , with the relevant changes to copy/read them in flashgg.
They are derived on full 2016 dataset, regression 74, for photons.
Bests,
Vittorio

column20:
Three things are done in this PR:

Update JetID prescription to include changed recommendation for transition region, see https://twiki.cern.ch/twiki/bin/view/CMS/JetID13TeVRun2016
Remove passesPuJetId call in tags, which always returns true anyway.
Consistently put in Loose Jet ID for all tags using jets, per JME recommendations.  You can see in https://indico.cern.ch/event/592313/contributions/2398387/attachments/1384663/2106630/JetID_JMARmeeting_7_12_2016.pdf that efficiency is >99% throughout, so no impact is expected on the analysis.   (The exception is VBF, which needs Tight Jet ID.)

column21:
Impact quite small as expected.  Yield of data changes by under 1% for all tags, and for signal the yield for "diagonal" process,tag pairs [3] always changes by under 0.25%.  A few off-diagonal tag,proc pairs change by more, which is not surprising or a cause for concern, because these cases have relatively few events, and both positive- and negative-weight events can move.  A complete list of the yield changes is at [4].
Seth
[3] "Diagonal" means that the process is targeted by the tag, e.g. WH with W --> jets and VHHadronic.
[4] https://sethzenz.web.cern.ch/sethzenz/cms/JetID_yield_compare.txt

column13: Update to with the full MET systematics for VH tags
column20:
Updates using non xy-corrected MET objects.  Had to keep the unclustered, JER, JEC, and photon components to the systematics separate, otherwise the systematic shifts are correlated incorrectly.
Also fixed a recent bug where the VHmet tag wouldn't pick up the systematics (Leptonic tags were unaffected).
column21:

Features in this PR:

HTXS tools (can be turned on or off with flag)
NoTag object for tracking QCD weights of signal not entering analysis
CentralHiggsFilter for HTXS for signal samples that didn't have HTXS stored, e.g. bbH

column13: Applying sigmaE/E systematic shift after smearing corrections
column20:
Hello,
this PR fixes the logic of the systematic shift of the sigmaE/E, applying it after the smearing corrections have been applied. This ensures that the nominal size of the shift is propagated to the smeared sigmaE/E.
Let me know if you have comments or questions,
Vittorio
column21:
Hello,
this PR fixes the logic of the systematic shift of the sigmaE/E, applying it after the smearing corrections have been applied. This ensures that the nominal size of the shift is propagated to the smeared sigmaE/E.
Let me know if you have comments or questions,
Vittorio

column21:
Hi @sethzenz
Ok so you can verify that the stored weights are identical e.g. taking the two ttH files:
i) before PDFWeightObjectProducer update
https://cmsweb.cern.ch/das/request?view=list&limit=50&instance=prod%2Fphys03&input=file%3D%2Fstore%2Fgroup%2Fphys_higgs%2Fcmshgg%2Fsethzenz%2Fflashgg%2FRunIISummer16-2_4_1-25ns_Moriond17%2F2_4_1%2FttHToGG_M125_13TeV_powheg_pythia8_v2%2FRunIISummer16-2_4_1-25ns_Moriond17-2_4_1-v0-RunIISummer16MiniAODv2-PUMoriond17_80X_mcRun2_asymptotic_2016_TrancheIV_v6-v1%2F170114_093929%2F0000%2FmyMicroAODOutputFile_12.root
ii) after PDFWeightObjectProducer update
https://cmsweb.cern.ch/das/request?input=file%3D%2Fstore%2Fuser%2Fgkrintir%2Fflashgg%2FRunIISummer16-2_4_2-25ns_Moriond17%2F2_4_2%2FttHToGG_M125_13TeV_powheg_pythia8_v2%2FRunIISummer16-2_4_2-25ns_Moriond17-2_4_2-v0-RunIISummer16MiniAODv2-PUMoriond17_80X_mcRun2_asymptotic_2016_TrancheIV_v6-v1%2F170310_113651%2F0000%2FmyMicroAODOutputFile_12.root&instance=prod%2Fphys03
For the TH samples we also checked that what we need are stored, e.g.
https://cmsweb.cern.ch/das/request?input=file%3D%2Fstore%2Fuser%2Fgkrintir%2Fflashgg%2FRunIISummer16-2_4_2-25ns_Moriond17%2F2_4_2%2FTHQ_HToGG_13TeV-madgraph-pythia8_TuneCUETP8M1%2FRunIISummer16-2_4_2-25ns_Moriond17-2_4_2-v0-RunIISummer16MiniAODv2-PUMoriond17_80X_mcRun2_asymptotic_2016_TrancheIV_v6-v1%2F170310_184042%2F0000%2FmyMicroAODOutputFile_1.root&instance=prod%2Fphys03
Before merging, let me then erase the last exception in MicroAODCustomize, before the TH samples are fully treated as signal:
https://github.com/gkrintir/flashgg-1/blob/b65e184360b8eb489a8ee753dc552376cd58b7f0/MicroAOD/python/MicroAODCustomize.py#L139-L140

column13: Updated the flashggDiPhotonSystematics_cfi.py file with latest SFs

column20:
Supersedes #896, includes all the same code plus some fixes and the extra needed files.  Two new nusiances, MCScaleGain1EB and MCScaleGain6EB, are added to workspaceStd.py.  Note to use this PR on top of an existing area it should suffice to do:
[merge the branch from this PR in flashgg as usual]
cd $CMSSW_BASE/src
git cms-merge-topic shervin86:Hgg_Gain_v1 -u
scram b -j 3
cp $CMSSW_BASE/src/flashgg/Systematics/data/Moriond17_74x_pho_s*.dat $CMSSW_BASE/src/EgammaAnalysis/ElectronTools/data

column20:
Changes:

added dumpers for VH leptonic tags
added cross sections for some backgrounds samples
modified ZHLeptonicTagProducer to take into account all possible muons or electrons pairs (i,j) except the pair built from the same lepton (i,i). This modification does not affect the results, as there was a minimum threshold (70 GeV) on the invariant mass of the lepton pair.
column21:
Changes:

added dumpers for VH leptonic tags
added cross sections for some backgrounds samples
modified ZHLeptonicTagProducer to take into account all possible muons or electrons pairs (i,j) except the pair built from the same lepton (i,i). This modification does not affect the results, as there was a minimum threshold (70 GeV) on the invariant mass of the lepton pair.

column13: VBF presel and accounting for internal conversions from Pythia8
column20:
A change to VBF selection to improve g+Jet discrimination [1]:

IDMVA preselection of -0.2 for VBF

And several changes related to "extra" events with internal conversions [2]:

Rename PythiaFilter to HardProcessFinalStateFilter for specificity
Messy by-hand merge of work from @edjtscott with my work on HardProcessFinalStateFilter (due to rebasing mistake on my part)
HardProcessFinalStateFilter not included by default (analysis decision to be discussed)
cross_section.json kfactor to account for extra events

[1] https://indico.cern.ch/event/598436/contributions/2529139/attachments/1434412/2205055/Zenz-VBF-Hgg-27Mar-v1.pdf
[2] Slide 4 of https://indico.cern.ch/event/598436/contributions/2529023/attachments/1434414/2205057/Zenz-News-Hgg-27Mar-v2.pdf

column20:
Ciao,
today I've run flashgg for the first time. I've run the examples of flashgg and they do not run out of the box, since there are some errors. I fixed them, if you think is useful (to avoid the debugging to new users) merge the pull request.
I've changed three things:
= In the Readme there is "cmsRun MicroAOD/test/microAODstd.py", if you don't specify the options "processType=sig datasetName=glugluh" the second step crashes
= cmsRun Taggers/test/diphotonsDumper_cfg.py doesn't work because:

the global tag was missing, causing an error related to GBRDWrapperRcd class
the variable r9 has changed name (r9->"old_r9" or "full5x5_r9")

column20:
Update flashgg so that it:

Compiles under CMSSW_8_0_28 (excluding Validation)
Runs Legacy ReReco

The following issues are outstanding from the update:

MET collections from reMiniAOD removed, and badMuonFilter removed because it has python issues.  MET update requires further investigation: https://hypernews.cern.ch/HyperNews/CMS/get/met/535/1/1.html
Tag and Probe removed, so Validation directory does not compile
EGM scale and smearing CMSSW tags assembled based on guesswork from two older messier tags.  The update requires investigation from experts to make sure it performs as expected: sethzenz:for-flashgg-smearer-conv-8_0_28

column13: Add b tag discriminant cmva v2

Preliminary updates to include the bTag discriminant CMVAv2 in flashgg along with CSVv2.

Pull request done so that changes to the code are easily visible to others in the Hgg working group.

column21:
Accepting this PR creates this warning in 92x:
 -------------------------------------------------------------------
 Warning: You are attempting to remake IVF secondary vertices from
          MiniAOD. If that was your intention, note that secondary
          vertices remade from MiniAOD will have somewhat degraded
          performance compared to those remade from RECO/AOD.
-------------------------------------------------------------------

To be investigated.  Nevertheless we are only adding new information to the jets, so I'll accept the PR for now to move forward...

column21:
Hi Seth,

I think the plan was remake the secondary vertices, since we don't use the
default primary vertex in H->yy and we actually create the set of jets
corresponding to different primary vertices so the secondary vertices are
to be regenerated correspondingly.

With regards,
Saranya Ghosh

column21:
Hi,
For HH->bbgg analysis, the CMVA (and maybe other b-taggers?) would be quite useful, even with respect the default primary vertex. In our case 99% of  the times the default vertex is selected.
This is just to request to keep default b-taggers computed with respect default primary vertex.
Which maybe means to save a default jet collection? (I'm not sure if it's already saved or not).

column13: Add b tag discriminant cmva v2

Pull request done so that changes to the code are easily visible to others in the Hgg working group.
column21:
Hi,

The values of the CSVv2 and the CMVAv2 will be stored also for the jet
collections of the zero-th primary vertex.

There is an option to not re-evaluate the secondary vertices, but then that
would be the case for all the jet collections in the way it is implemented.
The recommendation was to recompute the secondary vertices since for some
of the jet collections, the primary vertex is not the zero-th one.

If the flag is changed from true to false in:
https://github.com/cms-analysis/flashgg/pull/925/files#diff-2a98a870d06e8f73fb46887dee585251R210

Then the default set of secondary vertices will be used (that correspond
only to the zero-th primary vertex, even though the jet collection may be
made with a different primary vertex).

With regards,
Saranya Ghosh
…

 Which maybe means to save a default jet collection? (I'm not sure if it's

column21:
There's another wrinkle here, which is that by default we remake even the
0th vertex jets.  We should probably change this to save the old ones,
and/or  run a test where we save both the originals and the remade ones and
see how they compare.

column20:
Numerous code changes to allow compilation in CMSSW_9_2_0.  They are designed to have no impact on the code compiling and running in CMSSW_8_0_28.
Biggest changes are:

auto_ptr changed to unique_ptr everywhere
std::move added inside put command everywhere
selectors that are used in templates built off of SingleElementCollectionSelectorPlusEvent now need an operator() method that takes a Ref instead of a const object.  This required some changes to how things were templated, especially the CutBasedGenericObjectSelector
and CutBasedElectronObjectSelector
Special DataFormats xml file to reflect changes in pat objects, which is copied into place by setup_9_2_0.sh
Special setup_9_2_0.sh file which accesses updated branches

Many thanks to @lgray for helping with an elegant fix to the template issue, which also happens to have been created by him: https://github.com/cms-sw/cmssw/blame/09c3fce6626f70fd04223e7dacebf0b485f73f54/CommonTools/UtilAlgos/interface/SingleElementCollectionSelectorPlusEvent.h#L35
Note that the code will still require changes to run.  The one I'm sure of is removing special EGM id from customization, since those tags haven't been ported yet to CMSSW 9 as far as I know.

column20:
This PR contains all the code that is needed to reproduce workspaces/trees for the differential cross sections measurement.
The code has been kept up-to-date from my side with the flashgg master, but it would be helpful from a technical point of view to have a PR merged to avoid possible divergence of the projects.
I have performed checks before/after merge for standard and differential workspaces against the relevant branches and the number of entries in randomly picked tags is found to be the same. It would be great though if these results could be double-checked for standard workspaces.
Please let me know if you have comments or questions,
Vittorio

column13: Update for 2017 uAOD production (with HLT info)
column20:
This is an update which covers the needed updates for 2017 uAOD production for the HLT analysis.
I've included some updates necessary for running the updated tag-probe.  Linda may have some changes which are improvements, but those aren't needed for uAOD production, just the analysis of the HLT performance.

column21:
Hi Gouranga,
There was an update to the TnP code which should run successfully in 924.  Additionally, I removed or updated the Validation files which were not compiling in 92X.  As far as I understand, no one has used the removed plugins for quite some time.  This update reflects the currently recommended tag-probe producer from EGM. column13: get jets and met to run in uAOD for 2017 / 92x
column20:
Using a hack to restore the old "unscheduled behavior" from 80X, our jet and MET recipes now work as they used to.  In principle this is not ideal, it would be better to create tasks to tell CMSSW to run each specifically needed unscheduled modules, but that's not high priority as far as I'm aware.
Note I have removed the following compared with 80X:

HTXS (still need to update recipe)
Calls to setMetCorr, which probably wouldn't have made physically sensible changes with 2017 anyway

Objects in general cannot be considered validated. Everyone is encouraged to look at them!

column13: 2_7_5 catalog, SingleElectron + DY with fuller trig
column20: The samples here supersede the SingleElectron and DY samples in the 2_7_4 catalog.  The only difference is that extra trigger information for T&P studies is added, but the 2_7_4 SingleElectron and DY samples won't have their missing jobs resubmitted and will soon be deleted to save space.  Note that the 2_7_4 DoubleMuon are still the latest and will continue to be maintained.  I'll create a merged 2_7_4/2_7_5 catalog when 100% of all jobs are done, until/unless new features are required again.

column13: Tag and probe integration in standard flashgg sequence
column20:
It would be great if we could get this development by @simonepigazzini integrated in flashgg.
The code allows to run T&P on top of any diphoton collection (thus inheriting all the corrections machinery). The tag selection can use any photon or electron ID (the latter through matching by super-cluster).
The code has some conflicts, but I guess that they are all easily solvable,
Thanks,
Pasquale

column20:
Replaces #959.  Changes flashgg repo and setup scripts so that it compiles in 8_0_28, 9_2_8, or 9_4_0_patch1.  Running in the former 2 releases should be unaffected; the working recipe in 9_4_X is not yet finalized.
9_4_X requires several find-and-replace changes to TnP and to flashgg itself, which are implemented in perl, due to the change of a function name in cmssw.  These are implemented in perl in seutp_9_4_0.sh

column20:
If the list of LHE weight names and also the branch name of the LHEEventProduct are available in cross_section file for a sample, fggManageSamples automatically add the sum of all of those weights in the catalogue. A sample catalogue is also added under the champagne of THTest.
A parameter called "WeightName" is added to JobConfig. Using this parameter, sum of the value of the weight is used as "totalEvents" for lumi_weight calculation. In addition this parameter is passed to tagsDumper so each event is weighted accordingly.
In MicroAOD production, if the LHEEventProduct label for one sample is set in the cross_section json file, this collection is automatically asked to be kept in the output file.

In MicroAOD production, if the LHEEventProduct label for one sample is set in the cross_section json file, this collection is automatically asked to be kept in the output file.

column13: Move diphotons earlier in sequence, stop processing unles pt cut passed
column20:
Improves the previous filtering scheme for data by:

Requiring diphoton pt > 25,15 GeV for events to be stored (previously, no cut)
Stopping sequence processing immediately if no such diphoton exists

The former saves space, 20% on a random data file from SingleElectron 2017A.
The latter should save some CPU time (jet, electron, and muon sequences).

column20:
hi @sethzenz a PR with the latest JECs.
MET filters in microAODstd are fine.
The only thing to be careful with the 2017 data in workspaceStd is to remove the "Flag_eeBadScFilter" and instead add the "Flag_ecalBadCalibFilter" as in:
https://twiki.cern.ch/twiki/bin/viewauth/CMS/MissingETOptionalFiltersRun2#Moriond_2018
Btw I see them also hardoced in the taggers, e.g., in:
https://github.com/cms-analysis/flashgg/blob/master/Taggers/plugins/VHEtTagProducer.cc#L128
So it's also up to analysts to be informed.

column21:
Hi Seth,
thanks. For the final analysis we need this on basically all samples (HH, diphoton, g+Jets, all single higgs, data, t(t)g(g)). It is not super-urgent anyway (we'll have a workshop next week, after that we will have a clearer time scale). For the moment, your idea to have some samples to see that everything and then go back to another reproduction of the samples is ok.
The easiest sample for you to produce, useful for us, would be ZH since I have two photons and two jets with a mass peak.
Of course the HH samples would be the best. The exact names looking on DAS are these ones [1], node_SM would be the one highest priority. I remember a mail exchange between you @andreypz and @dmajumder about running on these samples but I don't remember if the problem there was solved. I also let them comment about the PDF (naively I think we should have the PDF info).
[1] https://cmsweb.cern.ch/das/request?view=list&limit=50&instance=prod%2Fglobal&input=dataset%3D%2F*GluGluToHHTo2B2G*node*%2FRunII*Fall17*%2F*MINIAOD*
thanks

column21:
@sethzenz  Indeed the MiniIsolation value is not stored in the Muon object. It would
be more clear and safer if the code is parametrized to get the working
point instead of the isolation cut. it is only used by ttHHadronic for some
non standard selection :
https://github.com/cms-analysis/flashgg/blob/fe06c355384cceaae74a0190ca3e82791b29d31f/Taggers/plugins/TTHHadronicTagProducer.cc#L286
if you agree we can ask them to adapt the code and their configurations.
otherwise i can work to use the standard modules of cmssw to read the
miniisolation value and import it into the muon object.

column20: I have modified the setup instructions, merged and rebased few merge-topics w.r.t. CMSSW_9_4_6 and put the commits in a new branch.
column21:
Previously the setup_9_4_X.sh was organized in blocks, with (in general) 3 components:

An explanation of what was about to happen.
an addpkg command to put in place the packages that were to be changed by a merge command
The merge command itself.

This PR mixes up some blocks and partially removes others, which is inefficient because the packages were added but without any changes.  I am going to start out by removing these entirely to check if we no longer need them:
-# Straightforward update for 8_0_28	
-echo "Tweaking ConfigToolBase.py to avoid assuming soft link path..."	
-git cms-addpkg FWCore/GuiBrowsers #temp-by hand	
-git cms-merge-topic -u sethzenz:for-flashgg-toolbase-9_4_0	

-echo "Setting up weight stuff..."	
-git cms-addpkg CommonTools/UtilAlgos	
-git cms-merge-topic -u sethzenz:for-flashgg-weightscount-9_4_0

If it works with those blocks out then they'll stay out, otherwise I'll put them back.  Either way I'll update the setup file to restore the structure.

column20:
Hi all,
these PR includes the latest version of the ttHHadronicMVA (30 variables instead of 35, sensitivity improved by about 8%), with the lastest 3D cuts defined with the optimal cuts found using bkg MC.
It also includes the latest SF for btagging (V3) from the btagging POG. The code has been tested both on Data and MC and is synch with our expectations.

column20:
Combines 3_1_0 and 3_1_1 catalogs, which use the same code except for a fix to the STXS info for VBF samples.  The 3_1_X catalog removes some overlaps that arose for 3 reasons:

Update of VBF samples to produce non-buggy versions
Rerun of samples that were still being producer
Operator error

Note that in all 3 cases the latter-produced sample is equivalent or better, so the former is removed.  A complete list of samples being removed is:

column21:
Combines 3_1_0 and 3_1_1 catalogs, which use the same code except for a fix to the STXS info for VBF samples.  The 3_1_X catalog removes some overlaps that arose for 3 reasons:

Update of VBF samples to produce non-buggy versions
Rerun of samples that were still being producer
Operator error

Note that in all 3 cases the latter-produced sample is equivalent or better, so the former is removed.  A complete list of samples being removed is:

column13: overlap remove for ttH leptonic analysis
column20:
Remove overlap between ttGG/ttG/tt sample as discussed in this report:
https://indico.cern.ch/event/754291/contributions/3133922/attachments/1713144/2762621/ttH_gg_overlapRemove_20180910.pdf
to remove overlap events, just require: "lead_Prompt != 0 && sublead_Prompt !=0 "
this code is a developing version and contains several unused members in TTHLeptonicTag.h, can be cleaned up for the future. However, the extra members won't interfere with any of the functionalities of this class

column21: Dear Samuel, thanks for this. It is very nice to have the possibility to remove this overlap in flashgg. However, I think it is not mergeable like this in flashgg because it modifies the tags definitions (in flashggTags and also directly in the leptonic tagger). Maybe this was meant only for people to be able to test it. However it would be very nice to have it included permanently in flashgg. So let's discuss this via email. Cheers, Julie

column13: Fix electrons SF plus TTHLeptonic and Hadronic tagger versatility
fix to have process.dumpPython() working in CMSSW_10_2_1
column20:
As discovered by @ArnabPurohit , process.dumpPython() fails with CMSSW_10_2_1.
It turns out that this has been found elsewhere in CMSSW (see cms-sw/cmssw#23774 ) but as far as we understood will the fix (cms-sw/cmssw#24168) will only be available in CMSSW_10_3_X (according to cms-sw/cmssw#24168 (comment) ).
We therefore propose a workaround which can be removed once flashgg moves to CMSSW_10_3_X.

column13: Catalogue for MET checks in ttH analysis
column20:
Two METs are available in the MicroAOD: "flashggMetsCorr" which is MET computed with JetMET recipe v2 (correction for EE noise) and "flashggMetsStd" which is computed without applying any correction ("Prompt2017").
All instances calling "flashggMets" under Systematics and Taggers have been updated to use
"flashggMetsCorr" by default.
Samples:

main analysis samples
one low mass signal (85 GeV)
HTXS samples
VH backgrounds
HH->bbgg signals

Still missing:

ttH JHU
diphoton background

column13: Add more jet information in microAOD to use resolve toptagger & add flags in TTHLeptonic tag to do overlap removal
column20:
commit 4ab377d is based on the previous PR: #1072
This new commit only adds flags in TTHLeptonic tagger to do overlap removal for ttgg/ttg/tt madgraph samples
commit b443999 adds more jet information in microAOD, so one can use resolved topTagger as described in slide 20 of https://indico.cern.ch/event/762838/contributions/3176550/attachments/1734127/2804005/ttHgg_Run2Studies_15Oct2018_SamuelMay.pdf
Both commits have been tested, they don't interfere with running flashgg workflow(use current test_cmds.sh), and the increase of mircoAOD size is less than 0.5%.

column20:
Muons scale factor update:

Include stat uncertainty in the SF error
Use the low pT SF from Muon POG to extend the pT range to 2 GeV (previously was 20 GeV) for ID
Introduce possibility to extend the last bin SF to a given pT threshold with double uncertainty (necessary for ISO, where no SF are provided for low pT muons)

On Dec 17, 2018, at 23:42, Samuel May <notifications@github.com<mailto:notifications@github.com>> wrote:

JECs are now read from FrontierProd db instead of relying on the sqlite db files.

Junquan Tao

column21:
Hi @jonathon-langford,
thank you for this. Does this include also updates from Ed about the recently approved STXS results?
Is this expect to impact anything else than STXS analyis? At a first look it doesn't sees so, which is good.
Few technical points:

please add the Emacs and Vi snippets at the bottom of any newly added c++ file to ensure that the
indentation is applied correctly by the automatic hook (please also check that the hook is correctly setup
in your working area, i.e. did you run the flashgg setup script?)
rollback the test file names to file:myMicroAOD.root instead of your custom ones.

column20:
New Rivet tool for 1.1 processes integrated into CMSSW_10_5_0: (see https://github.com/jonathon-langford/cmssw/blob/cmssw_STXS_1p1/SimDataFormats/HTXS/interface/HiggsTemplateCrossSections.h). This is required upstream from flashgg.


New HiggsClassification object automatically enters microAOD file when produced.


Updated TagTruthBase and all taggers to accommodate new HiggsClassification object


Configured ntuple dumper (Taggers/test/vbf_dumper_2017.py_ to work with with new metaConditions option. Example command:
cmsRun vbf_dumper_2017.py metaConditions=$CMSSW_BASE/src/flashgg/MetaData/data/MetaConditions/Era2016_RR-17Jul2018_v1.json maxEvents=-1
column21:
Hi Simone,


No problem! Was just composing an email to explain things further but you beat me to it :)


Firstly, no this does not include the updates from the HIG-18-029 analysis. Ed plans to make a PR after he has finished writing his thesis.


I was discussing this with Ed a few hours ago (so will cc him in), but this may indeed impact the recent STXS analysis. I have integrated the updated Rivet tool [1] upstream in CMSSW, which replaces the stage 1 information with 1.1. You can see the changes here: [2]. This means that the updates from Ed in their current state will not work after this PR, however he said he could make changes to his stuff to accommodate the 1.1. What do you think about this?


Concerning the upstream changes: it may not be appropriate to make an offical PR to CMSSW right now, since other analyses are still using the old stage 1 process definitions. Can you instead add a line to setup_flashgg.sh to merge these changes? You may need to add the following packages as well:
 git cms-addpkg SimDataFormats/HTXS
 git cms-addpkg GeneratorInterface/RivetInterface


For the technical points:


1) Are you referring to the newly added Rivet code: HiggsTemplateCrossSections.cc in CMSSW. Apart from that, there are no new c++ files in flashgg. And, yes I ran the flashgg setup script.


2) Will do. I don't think the diphotonsDumper_cfg.py file is configured for the new metaConditions anyway. Only the vbf_dumper_2017.py.


Cheers,

Jonathon

[1] - https://gitlab.cern.ch/LHCHIGGSXS/LHCHXSWG2/STXS
[2] - jonathon-langford/cmssw@23a4171

Is this expect to impact anything else than STXS analyis? At a first look it doesn't sees so, which is good.

Few technical points:

in your working area, i.e. did you run the flashgg setup script?)
  *   rollback the test file names to file:myMicroAOD.root instead of your custom ones.

@simonepigazzini there has been an update upstream so the new HiggsClassification object in CMSSW includes both stage 1 and stage 1.1 info (cms-sw/cmssw#26724). So you no longer need to make the "upstream" changes I suggested above. The new object should come automatically in the uAOD.
Not had time to check everything is compatible with the changes I made to the Taggers (i.e. the naming scheme of the functions: e.g. stage1_1_cat(). Also, since the new HiggsClassification also includes stage1 then the current flashgg should run without errors. Therefore I would suggest, not merging this PR just yet

column13: Correct the e-veto SFs for 2016 legacy and 2017 dataset
column20:
Correct the e-veto SFs for 2016 legacy in Systematics/python/flashggDiPhotonSystematics2016_cfi.py , according to slide 2 of https://indico.cern.ch/event/762183/contributions/3181242/attachments/1736403/2823204/201810_2016Legacy_e-veto_etc.pdf with 2016 legacy data samples, small changes on the SFs wrt previous results with 2016 rereco data samples.


Correct  the e-veto SFs for 2017 analyssi in Systematics/python/flashggDiPhotonSystematics2017_cfi.py : the e-veto scale factors for "dev_legacy_runII" 2017 dataset in are not the latest updated ones used for 2017 ttH (public for HC2018) [1] and 2017 STXS (public for Moriond2019) [2].  In [1] the numbers are the older ones before the PR#1089 [3].


[1] https://github.com/cms-analysis/flashgg/blob/master/Systematics/python/flashggDiPhotonSystematics_cfi.py#L26
[2] https://github.com/edjtscott/flashgg/blob/STXSstage1/Systematics/python/flashggDiPhotonSystematics_cfi.py#L26
[3] https://github.com/cms-analysis/flashgg/pull/1089/files

column13: Update handling of jets in microAOD
column20:
This PR simply updates the jet treatment in microAOD to be the same as it already was in 2017. Performed tests to check that the zeroth vertex jets agree with the miniAOD jets, and that the jets from the other vertices are sensible. These tests were done on 2016 & 2018 miniAOD for data, Drell-Yan and signal.
The second commit has two minor adjustments that were needed to get these local tests to work - I don't know if they will be required or wanted in the main repo.
At some point we expect further updates for the QGL and PUJID, but for now the code should be up-to-date.

column20:
Application of MET filters now performed through flashggMetFilters module.
All filters, except 1, are applied at the workspace production level.
List of filters is configurable by year and for data/MC. Currently set to the recommendations provided in [1].
The one filter that is not applied at workspace production level is done at microAOD production level because it must be rerun on top of miniAOD. I follow the recipe given in [1].

[1] https://twiki.cern.ch/twiki/bin/view/CMS/MissingETOptionalFiltersRun2#Analysis_Recommendations_for_ana

column21:
Hi @simonepigazzini @malcles ,
Julie pointed out that it's not optimal to have the ecalBadCalibFilter, which has to be rerun on top of miniAOD, be applied at microAOD production level. This is because it will filter events even for analyses that don't use MET.
So instead, I added a member variable to the Met data format which stores the result of the filter. Tags for which Met is important can then decide at workspace production level if they want to cut on the filter or not.

column13: Changes to get PhotonId MVA input corrections
Dev pho id input corrections clean
Modified systematics workflow for ttH tags
column20:
Implement modified systematics workflow for ttH tags to prevent excessive memory use by the large MVAs used by the ttH taggers. This is only an issue when running with full systematics (doSystematics=True), as an instance of each tagger object is created for each systematic variation by default.

When running with tthTagsOnly=True, evaluates all systematic variations in a single instance of the tagger object, looping over all relevant variations. Reduces memory use from 50GB -> 3GB.
When running with tthTagsOnly=False, disables large MVAs in the ttH tags (unless doSystematics=False, in which case full MVAs are still used). The systematics are run in the original way here, as I have not yet determined how to modify the systematics workflow for the ttH tags while maintaining the original workflow for the other tags.
@mhl0116 and I have verified that this modified workflow produces identical results as the original systematics workflow and that jobs no longer take up excessive memory leading to crashes (tested both locally and in batch with htcondor on lxplus).
To-do: how can we implement the memory-intensive MVAs when running all tags with the full systematics sequence? It seems like we would need to modify all taggers to loop over systematic variations inside the tagger. Or maybe there is an easier solution that I'm missing?

I'll take a look at the PR and merge it during this week.
simone

column20:
Implement modified systematics workflow for ttH tags to prevent excessive memory use by the large MVAs used by the ttH taggers. This is only an issue when running with full systematics (doSystematics=True), as an instance of each tagger object is created for each systematic variation by default.

When running with tthTagsOnly=True, evaluates all systematic variations in a single instance of the tagger object, looping over all relevant variations. Reduces memory use from 50GB -> 3GB.
When running with tthTagsOnly=False, disables large MVAs in the ttH tags (unless doSystematics=False, in which case full MVAs are still used). The systematics are run in the original way here, as I have not yet determined how to modify the systematics workflow for the ttH tags while maintaining the original workflow for the other tags.
@mhl0116 and I have verified that this modified workflow produces identical results as the original systematics workflow and that jobs no longer take up excessive memory leading to crashes (tested both locally and in batch with htcondor on lxplus).
To-do: how can we implement the memory-intensive MVAs when running all tags with the full systematics sequence? It seems like we would need to modify all taggers to loop over systematic variations inside the tagger. Or maybe there is an easier solution that I'm missing?
column21:
Hi @simonepigazzini , sorry for the late reply, I was away on vacation. @mhl0116 and I found that there was a bug with some systematics being assigned to the wrong tags. Let me first do some more rigorous checks to make sure everything is fixed.
I will confirm with you tomorrow.

column21:
Hi @simonepigazzini , @mhl0116 and I finished running some more detailed checks. We compared the m_gg distributions for every systematic in every ttH category, running over ~24k events, with both the old workflow and the new workflow [1]. The systematics match exactly between the two, with the exception of a single event which we believe is due to floating point rounding: TTHHadronicTag_3 has 2673 vs. 2674 events, all other tags match exactly.
So, the PR is ready to be merged now. Thanks.
[1] http://uaf-8.t2.ucsd.edu/~sjmay/2019/20190819_compareShape/

column13: Extended range for electron reco SF
column20:
extends the scale factor range to pt<10 gev (putting 1.0). In principle we shouldn't have those electrons but in some samples i see some with values like 9.88, maybe due to energy corrections. This is just applying 1 as SF to these low pt electrons to avoid crashes.
it fixes a bug introduced by met PR that prevented running workspaceStd.py

column13: Load parent and secondary dataset options in JobConfig
column20:
useParentDataset: load miniAOD collection while running on microAODs, add example for STXS 1.1 bin re-evaluation
secondaryDataset: load collections from user specified dataset (needed by H->4g analysis).

The two options are exclusive, useParentDataset has been tested by Ed and Jonathon while secondaryDataset might need further debug.

column20:
Implemented L1 pre-firing inefficiencies for ttH tags.
The pre-firing module will only be run if you select doL1Prefiring = True when running workspaceStd.py. If that option is selected, the MetaConditions file is then checked to see if pre-firing is appropriate for that year (i.e. don't apply if it is 2018), and if so, the weight files are set accordingly.
The effect is on the order of a few % for 2016 and 2017. Below are comparisons of workspaces with and without the L1 pre-firing weights applied. As a sanity check, 2018 is unchanged whether we select doL1Prefiring = True or doL1Prefiring = False. These were just quick checks on 1000 events in a ttHJetToGG_M125 file for each year, and we shouldn't quote any efficiency numbers from these.
I copied all the necessary weight files to /eos/cms/store/group/phys_higgs/cmshgg/flashgg-data/Taggers/data/.
2016: http://uaf-10.t2.ucsd.edu/~sjmay/ttH/L1Prefiring_comparison_2016/
2017: http://uaf-10.t2.ucsd.edu/~sjmay/ttH/L1Prefiring_comparison_2017/
2018: http://uaf-10.t2.ucsd.edu/~sjmay/ttH/L1Prefiring_comparison_2018/

column21: Hi Simone, I cleaned up the config a little bit with the last commit. The L1Prefire module was being kept in the sequence unnecessary cases, like when running on data, sometimes causing crashes. I made it more "user-proof" and ensured that if the user selects doL1Prefiring=True it only actually gets run and has the weights applied if it makes sense to do so (i.e. only for MC, only for 2016/2017).

Yes I agree that would make more sense. It was set up this way for the use case where one might want to dump the weight but not necessarily apply it to the diphoton object by default. However I don't think we really need that, and am sure we could get that working with a modified dipho collection anyway.
I am happy to make the necessary changes but would be on timescale of ~2weeks. I guess @sam-may can work with the current config til then?
